Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Cyborg Insect Networks for Exploration and Mapping (CINEMa)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Autonomous navigation in unknown and dynamic environments has been a major challenge for synthetic mobile robotic agents. On the other hand, insects can easily solve such complex navigational problems and demonstrate remarkably stable and optimized locomotion skills in almost any environment. This project aims to develop a mobile sensor network where insects are used as mobile biological-robotic (biobotic) nodes. Insects, in fact, build a "natural" sensor network through the use of their biological sensing organs and release of chemical, mechanical and optical cues to communicate the information to the rest of the group. In the scope of this project, a novel cyber-physical communication network will be established among the individual insect in addition to the aforementioned natural one. For this, insects will be equipped with synthetic electronic sensors to sense additional cues, neuromuscular stimulation systems to direct the control of the insect and microcontrollers with radios to establish an RF link between the insects. This novel network will enable operation of insect biobots in complicated and uncertain dynamic environments for applications such as environmental sensing and search-and-rescue operations after natural disasters.

The unique interdisciplinary nature of this project will help engineers to reach to younger generations and train them to be able to look at engineering problems from a cyberphysical systems point of view. Planned activities include development of lab modules and demos by undergraduate and graduate students to teach K-12 students and their teachers through our on-going collaborations with educational partners. These demos will also be instrumental during nation level efforts to promote graduate education to underrepresented minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project titled “CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Cyborg Insect Networks for Exploration and Mapping (CINEMa)” was executed under three PIs from Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering at North Carolina State University. Prof. Alper Y Bozkurt is an expert in neural interfaces and stimulation; Prof. Edgar Lobaton’s research focuses on mapping and localization and Prof.  Mihail L Sichitiu handled the sensor networks aspect of the project.

The overarching goal of this project was to enhance the technological infrastructure for Cyber­Physical Systems by establishing the fundamental physical and algorithmic building blocks of a biobotic swarm and producing a cyber­physical sensor network among the individuals of non­eusocial insects such as cockroaches and moths with an aim of searching and rescuing victims after natural disasters such as earthquakes.

The research tasks towards achieving this goal were:

  1. Backpack development for biobots
  2. Biobotic control design
  3. Tracking of locomotion-controlled insect biobots
  4. Learning biobotic motion models
  5. Individual and swarm biobotic control
  6. Hybrid MAC design with the radio carried by the backpacks
  7. Localization of the backpack radios
  8. Hybrid mapping and exploration using backpack radios and on-board inertial measurement units and acoustic devices

The very exciting research outcomes of these tasks were disseminated through 2 Ph.D. disserations, 5 published peer reviewed journal articles and 15 peer-reviewed conference articles. Our papers became a Best Paper Finalist in IEEE WisNet 2016 and won the best paper award in GOMACTECH 2014.

The project was highly visible in the mass media and contributed the promotion of the concept of cyberphysical systems to the general public. Below is a list of our specific activities:

  • The project outcomes have been presented at conferences such as the Intl. Conf. on Information Processing in Sensor Networks (IPSN), IEEE Conference on Wireless Sensors and Sensor Networks, IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Conference and IEEE Biomedical Circuits and Systems Conference. The PIs gave invited talks under American Scientist - Science Communicators of North Carolina Joint Speaker Series; served as a panelist for the "Science in the Movies: Insects!" event organized by NCSU and North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences; presented to a community of adults (age 50+) as part of a seminar series for the Osher Lifelong Learning Institute (OLLI) at NCSU; participated to a scientific symposium at the national conference for the Society for the Advancement of Hispanics/Chicanos and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS) and gave a talk under the Science Cafe in the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences. The outcomes of the project was also presented to a large community of scientist and researchers at  following meetings and venues: Keynote speech in Intel India Innovation Day, University of Pennsylvania, University of California at Berkeley, Cornell University, Drexel University, Washington State University, Tulane University, Annual STEM Professional Development Networking Conference at North Carolina Central University (a NC based HBU), Intel Portland, IBM at RTP, Global Special Operation Forces Symposium “Anticipate the Future”, IMEC Belgium and Rotary Club of Raleigh.
  • Our team presented at the NCSU outreach event Engineering Bits & Bytes Day and participated in the BugFest four times, the largest museum event with around 40,000 people attending the event. We also offered a lecture at the Windows on the World stage during the BugFest. The team also presented at the Marbles’ Future Me Kids Career Fair and a group of students visiting us from Toisnot Middle School and Spring Creek High School.  The team also presented a poster during the Science House Imhotep Academy annual presentation day (for 5th to 8th girls from underrepresented communities). Five press releases were published about the research progress and this resulted with several news articles in several prominent media outlets (including Nature News, BBC World News (live interview), NPR (live interview), CNN, Discovery Channel (live interview), Newsweek (2 pages dedicated)). Our research was highlighted as a 6 minute video under the Science Channel show Through the Wormhole where the research was explained by Morgan Freeman. Our videos uploaded on Youtube were viewed by more than 1M viewers. The project also became a question in the TV contest Jeopardy! and became a comic strip under the academic comic strip Ph.D. Comics. 
  • The research products of this projects also became lab modules under ECE 505 Neural Interface Engineering and ECE 792 Applications of Grapical Models courses at NCSU. These lab modules are essential to attract the attention of electrical engineering students to topics related to biomedical engineering that results with products saving or improving the quality of life.
  • As part of the project, we developed a robotic platform called the WolfBot, which we use to simulate insects and provide a testbed to evaluate the developed localization and mapping strategies. This platform was also used for academic outreach to offers demos such as during the Open House at NCSU.
